title: Introduction to Python
content:
Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for its simplicity and readability. Created by Guido van Rossum in 1991, Python emphasizes code readability with its use of significant indentation.

Key features:
- Easy to learn and read
- Dynamically typed
- Extensive standard library
- Great for beginners and experts alike
codeExample:
# Your first Python program
print("Hello, World!")

# Python is simple and readable
name = "TechVerse"
print(f"Welcome to {name}!")
tryStarter:
# Try printing your own message
print("Your message here")

title: Variables and Data Types
content:
Variables in Python are containers for storing data. Python is dynamically typed, meaning you don't need to declare variable types explicitly.

Common data types:
- int: Integers (1, 42, -7)
- float: Decimals (3.14, -0.5)
- str: Strings ("hello", 'world')
- bool: Booleans (True, False)
- list: Ordered collections [1, 2, 3]
- dict: Key-value pairs {"key": "value"}
codeExample:
# Variables and types
name = "Alice"      # str
age = 25            # int
height = 5.6        # float
is_student = True   # bool

# Check types
print(type(name))   # <class 'str'>
print(type(age))    # <class 'int'>

# String formatting
print(f"{name} is {age} years old")
tryStarter:
# Create your own variables
my_name = ""
my_age = 0

print(f"Hello, {my_name}!")

title: Operators
content:
Python supports various operators for performing operations on variables and values.

Arithmetic: +, -, *, /, //, %, **
Comparison: ==, !=, <, >, <=, >=
Logical: and, or, not
Assignment: =, +=, -=, *=, /=
codeExample:
# Arithmetic operators
a, b = 10, 3
print(a + b)   # 13 (addition)
print(a - b)   # 7 (subtraction)
print(a * b)   # 30 (multiplication)
print(a / b)   # 3.33 (division)
print(a // b)  # 3 (floor division)
print(a % b)   # 1 (modulus)
print(a ** b)  # 1000 (exponent)

# Comparison operators
print(a > b)   # True
print(a == b)  # False
tryStarter:
# Try different operators
x = 15
y = 4

print(x + y)
print(x % y)

title: Strings
content:
Strings are sequences of characters enclosed in quotes. Python provides many built-in methods for string manipulation.

Key operations:
- Concatenation with +
- Repetition with *
- Slicing with [start:end]
- Methods: upper(), lower(), split(), join(), strip()
codeExample:
text = "Hello, Python!"

# String methods
print(text.upper())      # HELLO, PYTHON!
print(text.lower())      # hello, python!
print(text.replace("Python", "World"))

# Slicing
print(text[0:5])         # Hello
print(text[-7:-1])       # Python

# String formatting
name = "Alice"
age = 25
print(f"{name} is {age} years old")
tryStarter:
# Practice string manipulation
message = "python is awesome"

# Make it uppercase
print(message.upper())

title: Lists
content:
Lists are ordered, mutable collections that can hold items of different types. They are one of the most versatile data structures in Python.

Key operations:
- append(): Add item to end
- insert(): Add item at position
- remove(): Remove first occurrence
- pop(): Remove and return item
- sort(): Sort in place
codeExample:
# Creating lists
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
mixed = [1, "hello", 3.14, True]

# Accessing elements
print(fruits[0])      # apple
print(fruits[-1])     # cherry

# Modifying lists
fruits.append("orange")
fruits.insert(1, "mango")
print(fruits)

# List slicing
print(numbers[1:4])   # [2, 3, 4]
tryStarter:
# Create and modify a list
my_list = [1, 2, 3]
my_list.append(4)
print(my_list)

title: Conditionals
content:
Conditional statements allow you to execute different code based on conditions. Python uses if, elif, and else keywords.

Key concepts:
- Indentation is crucial
- Conditions evaluate to True or False
- elif chains multiple conditions
- else catches all other cases

title: Loops
content:
Loops allow you to execute code repeatedly. Python has two main loop types: for and while.

for loops iterate over sequences
while loops continue until a condition is False
break exits the loop
continue skips to next iteration

title: Functions
content:
Functions are reusable blocks of code that perform specific tasks. They help organize code and avoid repetition.

Key concepts:
- def keyword defines a function
- Parameters receive input values
- return sends back a result
- Default parameters provide fallback values
- *args and **kwargs for variable arguments
codeExample:
# Basic function
def greet(name):
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

print(greet("Alice"))

# Function with default parameter
def power(base, exp=2):
    return base ** exp

print(power(3))      # 9
print(power(2, 4))   # 16

# Multiple return values
def get_stats(numbers):
    return min(numbers), max(numbers), sum(numbers)/len(numbers)

min_val, max_val, avg = get_stats([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
print(f"Min: {min_val}, Max: {max_val}, Avg: {avg}")
tryStarter:
# Create your own function
def add_numbers(a, b):
    return a + b

result = add_numbers(5, 3)
print(result)

title: Dictionaries
content:
Dictionaries store data as key-value pairs. They are unordered, mutable, and indexed by keys (not positions).

Key operations:
- Access: dict[key] or dict.get(key)
- Add/Update: dict[key] = value
- Remove: del dict[key] or dict.pop(key)
- Iterate: keys(), values(), items()
codeExample:
# Creating dictionaries
person = {
    "name": "Alice",
    "age": 25,
    "city": "New York"
}

# Accessing values
print(person["name"])       # Alice
print(person.get("age"))    # 25

# Modifying
person["email"] = "alice@example.com"
person["age"] = 26

# Iterating
for key, value in person.items():
    print(f"{key}: {value}")

title: List Comprehensions
content:
List comprehensions provide a concise way to create lists based on existing lists or other iterables. They combine loops and conditionals into a single line.

Syntax: [expression for item in iterable if condition]
codeExample:
# Basic list comprehension
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
squares = [x**2 for x in numbers]
print(squares)  # [1, 4, 9, 16, 25]

# With condition
even = [x for x in numbers if x % 2 == 0]
print(even)  # [2, 4]

# String manipulation
words = ["hello", "world"]
upper = [w.upper() for w in words]
print(upper)  # ["HELLO", "WORLD"]

# Nested comprehension
matrix = [[i*j for j in range(1, 4)] for i in range(1, 4)]
print(matrix)  # [[1,2,3], [2,4,6], [3,6,9]]
tryStarter:
# Create a list comprehension
nums = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
doubled = [x * 2 for x in nums]
print(doubled)

title: Error Handling
content:
Error handling allows your program to gracefully handle exceptions instead of crashing. Python uses try, except, else, and finally blocks.

Common exceptions:
- ValueError: Invalid value
- TypeError: Wrong type
- ZeroDivisionError: Division by zero
- FileNotFoundError: File doesn't exist

title: Classes and OOP
content:
Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) organizes code into classes and objects. Classes are blueprints for creating objects with attributes and methods.

Key concepts:
- __init__: Constructor method
- self: Reference to current instance
- Inheritance: Derive new classes from existing ones
- Encapsulation: Hide internal details

title: File Handling
content:
Python provides built-in functions for reading and writing files. The 'with' statement ensures proper file handling and automatic closing.

Modes:
- 'r': Read (default)
- 'w': Write (overwrites)
- 'a': Append
- 'r+': Read and write
codeExample:
# Writing to a file
with open('example.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Hello, World!\n')
    f.write('Python file handling\n')

# Reading entire file
with open('example.txt', 'r') as f:
    content = f.read()
    print(content)

# Reading line by line
with open('example.txt', 'r') as f:
    for line in f:
        print(line.strip())

# Appending to file
with open('example.txt', 'a') as f:
    f.write('New line added\n')
tryStarter:
# Create and read a file
with open('test.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('My first file!')

with open('test.txt', 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())

title: Modules and Packages
content:
Modules are Python files containing reusable code. Packages are directories of modules. Python has a rich standard library and supports third-party packages via pip.

Import styles:
- import module
- from module import function
- import module as alias
codeExample:
# Importing built-in modules
import math
print(math.sqrt(16))  # 4.0
print(math.pi)        # 3.14159...

import random
print(random.randint(1, 10))

# Selective import
from datetime import datetime
print(datetime.now())

# Using alias
import json as j
data = {"name": "Alice"}
print(j.dumps(data))

# Common modules:
# os - Operating system interface
# sys - System-specific parameters
# re - Regular expressions
# collections - Specialized containers
tryStarter:
# Try importing modules
import random

# Generate random number
num = random.randint(1, 100)
print(f"Random number: {num}")

title: Decorators and Generators
content:
Decorators modify the behavior of functions. Generators are functions that yield values one at a time, enabling memory-efficient iteration.

Decorators use @ syntax
Generators use yield instead of return
Both are powerful Python features
codeExample:
# Decorator example
def timer(func):
    import time
    def wrapper(*args):
        start = time.time()
        result = func(*args)
        print(f"Time: {time.time() - start:.4f}s")
        return result
    return wrapper

@timer
def slow_function():
    import time
    time.sleep(1)
    return "Done"

print(slow_function())

# Generator example
def countdown(n):
    while n > 0:
        yield n
        n -= 1

for num in countdown(5):
    print(num)  # 5, 4, 3, 2, 1

# Generator expression
squares = (x**2 for x in range(10))
print(list(squares))

title: Introduction to JavaScript
content:
JavaScript is the programming language of the web. It runs in browsers and on servers (Node.js), making it essential for web development.

Key features:
- Dynamic and loosely typed
- Event-driven programming
- Supports functional and OOP paradigms
- Runs everywhere (browsers, servers, mobile)
tryStarter:
// Try printing your own message
console.log("Your message here");

title: Variables and Data Types
content:
JavaScript has three ways to declare variables: var (old), let (block-scoped), and const (immutable reference).

Primitive types:
- string: Text values
- number: All numbers (int & float)
- boolean: true or false
- undefined: No value assigned
- null: Intentional absence of value
- symbol: Unique identifiers
codeExample:
// Variable declarations
let name = "Alice";      // Can be reassigned
const age = 25;          // Cannot be reassigned
var legacy = "old way";  // Avoid using var

// Data types
const text = "Hello";    // string
const num = 42;          // number
const decimal = 3.14;    // number
const isActive = true;   // boolean
let unknown;             // undefined
const empty = null;      // null

// Check type
console.log(typeof name);    // string
console.log(typeof age);     // number

title: Operators
content:
JavaScript supports arithmetic, comparison, logical, and assignment operators.

Arithmetic: +, -, *, /, %, **
Comparison: ==, ===, !=, !==, <, >, <=, >=
Logical: &&, ||, !
Assignment: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

Note: === checks type AND value, == only checks value
codeExample:
// Arithmetic operators
let a = 10, b = 3;
console.log(a + b);   // 13
console.log(a - b);   // 7
console.log(a * b);   // 30
console.log(a / b);   // 3.33...
console.log(a % b);   // 1
console.log(a ** b);  // 1000

// Comparison (use === for strict equality)
console.log(5 == "5");   // true (type coercion)
console.log(5 === "5");  // false (strict)

// Logical operators
console.log(true && false);  // false
console.log(true || false);  // true
console.log(!true);          // false

title: Strings
content:
Strings are sequences of characters. JavaScript provides many methods for string manipulation and supports template literals for easy formatting.

Common methods:
- length: String length
- toUpperCase()/toLowerCase()
- substring()/slice()
- split()/join()
- includes()/indexOf()

title: Arrays
content:
Arrays are ordered collections of values. JavaScript arrays are dynamic and can hold mixed types.

Common methods:
- push()/pop(): Add/remove from end
- shift()/unshift(): Remove/add from start
- slice()/splice(): Extract/modify
- map()/filter()/reduce(): Transform arrays

title: Conditionals
content:
Conditionals control program flow based on conditions. JavaScript supports if/else, switch, and the ternary operator.

Truthy values: true, non-zero numbers, non-empty strings, objects
Falsy values: false, 0, "", null, undefined, NaN

title: Loops
content:
Loops repeat code execution. JavaScript has for, while, do-while, and iteration methods like forEach, for...of, for...in.

break: Exit loop immediately
continue: Skip to next iteration

title: Functions
content:
Functions are reusable code blocks. JavaScript supports function declarations, expressions, and arrow functions.

Arrow functions: Concise syntax with =>
Default parameters: Fallback values
Rest parameters: Variable number of arguments

title: Objects
content:
Objects store key-value pairs and are fundamental to JavaScript. They can contain properties and methods.

Access: dot notation or bracket notation
Methods: Functions as object properties
Shorthand: ES6 property and method shorthand

title: Array Methods
content:
Modern JavaScript provides powerful array methods for functional programming. These methods don't modify the original array.

map(): Transform each element
filter(): Keep elements that pass test
reduce(): Accumulate to single value
find()/findIndex(): Search for elements

title: Promises and Async/Await
content:
JavaScript handles asynchronous operations with Promises and async/await. These patterns prevent callback hell and make async code readable.

Promise states: pending, fulfilled, rejected
async/await: Syntactic sugar for Promises
try/catch: Handle async errors

title: Destructuring and Spread
content:
Destructuring extracts values from arrays/objects. Spread operator (...) expands elements. These ES6 features make code concise.

Array destructuring: [a, b] = arr
Object destructuring: {x, y} = obj
Spread: [...arr] or {...obj}

title: Classes and OOP
content:
ES6 introduced class syntax for object-oriented programming. Classes are syntactic sugar over JavaScript's prototype-based inheritance.

class: Define a class
constructor: Initialize instances
extends: Inherit from parent class
static: Class-level methods

title: Modules (ES6)
content:
ES6 modules help organize code into separate files. Each file is a module with its own scope.

export: Make code available to other modules
import: Use code from other modules
default export: Main export of a module
named exports: Multiple exports per module

title: Error Handling
content:
Error handling prevents crashes and provides meaningful feedback. JavaScript uses try/catch/finally for synchronous code and .catch() for Promises.

Error types: Error, TypeError, ReferenceError, SyntaxError
throw: Create custom errors
finally: Always executes

title: Introduction to TypeScript
content:
TypeScript is JavaScript with static types. It helps catch errors early and improves code quality through type checking.

Benefits:
- Catch errors at compile time
- Better IDE support (autocomplete, refactoring)
- Self-documenting code
- Works with existing JavaScript

title: Basic Types
content:
TypeScript provides several basic types for common values. These types form the foundation of the type system.

Primitive types: string, number, boolean
Special types: any, unknown, void, never, null, undefined
Array types: number[], Array<string>
Tuple types: [string, number]

title: Interfaces
content:
Interfaces define the shape of objects. They're a powerful way to define contracts in your code.

Optional properties: property?
Readonly properties: readonly property
Function signatures: (param: type) => returnType
Extending interfaces: interface B extends A

title: Type Aliases and Unions
content:
Type aliases create custom type names. Union types allow a value to be one of several types. Intersection types combine multiple types.

type alias: type Name = ...
Union: type A | type B
Intersection: type A & type B
Literal types: "success" | "error"

title: Generics
content:
Generics allow you to write reusable code that works with different types while maintaining type safety. They're like type parameters.

Generic functions: function<T>(param: T): T
Generic interfaces: interface Box<T> { value: T }
Constraints: <T extends SomeType>
Multiple type parameters: <T, U>

title: Classes in TypeScript
content:
TypeScript enhances JavaScript classes with access modifiers, abstract classes, and better type support.

Access modifiers: public, private, protected
readonly: Immutable properties
abstract: Classes that can't be instantiated
implements: Class implements interface

title: Advanced Types
content:
TypeScript provides utility types for common type transformations. These help manipulate and combine types.

Partial<T>: All properties optional
Required<T>: All properties required
Pick<T, K>: Select specific properties
Omit<T, K>: Exclude specific properties
Record<K, V>: Create object type

title: Decorators
content:
Decorators are a way to add metadata and modify classes, methods, and properties. They're widely used in frameworks like Angular and NestJS.

Class decorators: @decorator class
Method decorators: @decorator method()
Property decorators: @decorator property
Parameter decorators: method(@decorator param)

title: Introduction to Java
content:
Java is a strongly-typed, object-oriented programming language. It follows the 'Write Once, Run Anywhere' principle through the JVM.

Key features:
- Platform independent (JVM)
- Strong type system
- Automatic memory management
- Rich standard library

title: Variables and Data Types
content:
Java is statically typed - every variable must have a declared type. Java has primitive types and reference types.

Primitives: byte, short, int, long, float, double, boolean, char
Reference types: String, Arrays, Objects
Type inference: var (Java 10+)

title: Control Flow
content:
Control flow statements direct program execution. Java supports if-else, switch, and various loop constructs.

Conditionals: if, else if, else, switch
Loops: for, while, do-while, enhanced for
Control: break, continue, return

title: Methods
content:
Methods are blocks of code that perform specific tasks. Java supports method overloading and various parameter types.

Method signature: returnType name(parameters)
Overloading: Same name, different parameters
Varargs: variable number of arguments

title: Classes and Objects
content:
Java is fully object-oriented. Classes are blueprints for objects, containing fields (data) and methods (behavior).

Class components: fields, constructors, methods
Object creation: new ClassName()
this: Reference to current object
static: Class-level members

title: Inheritance
content:
Inheritance allows classes to inherit fields and methods from parent classes. Java supports single inheritance with extends.

extends: Inherit from parent class
super: Access parent class members
@Override: Override parent methods
final: Prevent inheritance/override

title: Interfaces
content:
Interfaces define contracts that classes must implement. They enable abstraction and multiple inheritance of type.

interface: Define contract
implements: Class implements interface
default methods: Implementation in interface
functional interfaces: Single abstract method

title: Collections
content:
Java Collections Framework provides data structures and algorithms. Common interfaces include List, Set, Map, and Queue.

List: ArrayList, LinkedList
Set: HashSet, TreeSet
Map: HashMap, TreeMap
Queue: PriorityQueue, LinkedList

title: Introduction to C
content:
C is a foundational systems programming language. Created in 1972, it provides low-level memory access and efficient code.

Key features:
- Direct memory manipulation
- Minimal runtime overhead
- Foundation for many languages
- Systems and embedded programming

title: Variables and Data Types
content:
C requires explicit type declarations. Understanding data types and their sizes is crucial for memory management.

Integer types: char, short, int, long
Floating point: float, double
Modifiers: signed, unsigned
sizeof: Get size in bytes

title: Operators
content:
C supports a rich set of operators including arithmetic, relational, logical, bitwise, and assignment operators.

Arithmetic: +, -, *, /, %
Relational: ==, !=, <, >, <=, >=
Logical: &&, ||, !
Bitwise: &, |, ^, ~, <<, >>

title: Control Flow
content:
Control flow statements direct program execution based on conditions and loops.

Conditionals: if, else, switch
Loops: for, while, do-while
Jumps: break, continue, goto, return

title: Functions
content:
Functions organize code into reusable blocks. C functions can return values and accept parameters by value or by pointer.

Function prototype: returnType name(params);
Pass by value: Copy of argument
Pass by reference: Using pointers
Recursion: Function calling itself

title: Arrays and Strings
content:
Arrays are contiguous memory blocks. Strings are character arrays terminated with null ('\0').

Arrays: Fixed size, same type elements
Strings: char arrays with null terminator
Multidimensional: Arrays of arrays
String functions: strlen, strcpy, strcat, strcmp

title: Pointers
content:
Pointers store memory addresses. They're essential for dynamic memory, arrays, and function parameters.

& : Address-of operator
* : Dereference operator
Pointer arithmetic: Move through memory
NULL: Invalid/empty pointer

title: Structs
content:
Structures group related data of different types. They're the foundation for complex data types in C.

struct: Define structure
typedef: Create type alias
. operator: Access member
-> operator: Access via pointer

title: Memory Management
content:
C provides manual memory management through malloc, calloc, realloc, and free. Proper management prevents leaks and corruption.

malloc: Allocate memory
calloc: Allocate and zero-initialize
realloc: Resize allocation
free: Release memory

title: File I/O
content:
C provides file operations through FILE pointers and functions like fopen, fclose, fread, fwrite, fprintf, fscanf.

fopen: Open file (r, w, a modes)
fclose: Close file
fprintf/fscanf: Formatted I/O
fread/fwrite: Binary I/O

title: Introduction to C++
content:
C++ extends C with object-oriented features, generic programming, and modern abstractions. It's used for systems, games, and performance-critical applications.

Key features:
- Object-oriented programming
- Templates (generic programming)
- STL (Standard Template Library)
- RAII (Resource management)

title: Variables and Types
content:
C++ has a rich type system with type inference (auto), references, and modern initialization syntax.

auto: Type inference
references: Aliases to variables
const: Immutable values
initializer lists: Uniform initialization

title: Control Flow
content:
C++ supports traditional control flow with modern enhancements like range-based for loops and structured bindings.

if with initializer: if (init; condition)
Range-based for: for (auto& x : container)
switch with fallthrough attribute

title: Functions
content:
C++ functions support overloading, default arguments, references, and lambda expressions.

Overloading: Same name, different parameters
Default arguments: Optional parameters
Lambdas: Anonymous functions
Trailing return type: auto f() -> type

title: Classes and Objects
content:
C++ is a full-featured object-oriented language with classes, encapsulation, constructors, and destructors.

Access modifiers: public, private, protected
Constructors: Initialize objects
Destructors: Cleanup when destroyed
this pointer: Reference to current object

title: Inheritance
content:
C++ supports single and multiple inheritance, virtual functions for polymorphism, and abstract classes.

Base class: Parent class
Derived class: Inherits from base
virtual: Enable polymorphism
override: Mark overridden methods
pure virtual: Abstract methods (= 0)

title: Templates
content:
Templates enable generic programming. Write code once that works with any type.

Function templates: Work with any type
Class templates: Generic classes
Template specialization: Custom for specific types
Variadic templates: Variable number of types

title: STL Containers
content:
The Standard Template Library provides powerful container classes for data storage and manipulation.

vector: Dynamic array
map: Key-value pairs (sorted)
unordered_map: Hash table
set: Unique elements (sorted)
deque: Double-ended queue

title: Smart Pointers
content:
Smart pointers automatically manage memory, preventing leaks and dangling pointers. RAII (Resource Acquisition Is Initialization) pattern.

unique_ptr: Exclusive ownership
shared_ptr: Shared ownership (reference counted)
weak_ptr: Non-owning reference
make_unique/make_shared: Factory functions

title: Modern C++ Features
content:
Modern C++ (C++11/14/17/20) introduces powerful features for cleaner, safer, and more expressive code.

C++11: auto, lambdas, move semantics, smart pointers
C++14: Generic lambdas, return type deduction
C++17: Structured bindings, if constexpr, std::optional
C++20: Concepts, ranges, coroutines, modules
